text: [music]
[music] The third floor is a
visualization company. Their roots go
all the way back to working with George
Lucas at the ranch. And since then, they
went on to work on the major
blockbusters that have been released in
Hollywood for the past 20, 30 years. I
was really excited to be working with
the third [music] floor on this project.
Being able to bring them into this
process and hearing their pitch for the
approach on how to handle the animation
was first of all we could have that
cinematic conversation. We could talk
about what Quenton movies are like, how
we want to emulate the different things
that we see in Quenton Tarantino movies
and bring that to our piece. There's
also the animation [music] part of it.
They just did this great movie, The
Predator, Killer of Killers. And I loved
the visual style of that film where they
animated on twos. There was a lot of
really creative [music] ways that they
were able to slip backgrounds and do
things to to kind of draw you into that
story. And being able to bring that to
bear on this [music] project, I thought
was a perfect marriage of those things.
>> Animating on twos is actually something
invented 100 years ago. It was to save
[music] paper, save drawings, and to do
12 drawings per second instead of 24.
Take those 12 drawings and exaggerate
them just a little bit to actually
account for fluid motion.
So, we really dove into the lighting,
the cameras, [music] the distortions,
the hellations, all those little
imperfections that really make Quinton
Tarantino's like classic film [music]
look. And he put those two together with
this kind of crisp, snappy feel of a
traditional animating on to um [music]
with this filmic lighting look and it
produced a really fascinating result.
>> You think you are safe?
Well, I say
>> the the UEE workflow lends itself really
well to animated production. We went out
and shot a placeholder motion capture so
that we could stand the whole thing up
in Unreal. There's an actor moving
around on the stage. You're looking
[music] at the monitor and they're
moving around as an animated character.
So, there's a lot you can do with
composition and camera work on the day
that would have taken a lot more cycles
with boards or with with [music] previs
back in the day. This liveaction kind of
approach to animating in [music] real
time kind of starts in the data position
and goes to this stylization [music]
kind of creative tweaking process. We
get that into our character models to
hey is this feeling like the correct
performance or is this feeling like we
need to really push the stylization
[music]
and we're looking at it from that
animation lens. And so we're going to
push that through the animators to tweak
that to make sure [music] it all is
cohesive in a stylized presentation. and
it's really hitting the mark that we're
going for.
[screaming]
>> You're using animation to almost
heighten the story. If we need some more
emphasis on some dialogue, we're going
to put in some keys here and there. And
I think that brings a lot of creative
choices to the table. It keeps us in a
style that doesn't feel like something
that we've seen before, [music]
something fresh and something new.
